ancillaries.colour_text: People always resent authority, but reminding them of the fact can prove useful to the larger cause.
Sir: I can think of no subject more stirring, heroic, patriotic or inspiring to my pen than your own achievements.
I do not daub warts and cankers! I paint heroes!
There is risk in the aery realms, but is there not also glory, honour, scientific curiosity, and a very good view of the enemy?
Money, sir, money. Your army works not because it has bullets, men or cannon. It has money!
Do we have to fight a war? It sounds deucedly vulgar, and quite likely to ruin this cravat.
A biographical tome exists to enhance the reputations of the subject and the author's patron, not that of the miserable scribbler.
A man whose very bones are hewn from ship's timbers is worth keeping close!
The powerful always have enemies to be guarded against.
Sometimes it can be a good idea to keep two sets of account books.
The man who keeps a ship afloat rarely wants for friends at sea.
I've not plugged the leak, but I have made this rather attractive chaise-longue!
If God had meant us to look after the poor he would have created more money for the rich, sir.
Sir, the achievements and glories of Rome and Greece are the foundations of our own poor efforts!
The people must be protected. The people will be protected. The people will show no mercy to their enemies.
A man who commands a good table will never want for friends!
A young man in search of military employment and preferment has many uses.
A man who will cut down - at the full gallop, mind! - any foe is a worthy ally.
Ha! I have shat myself, ha ha!
A commemorative medal - and the owner thereof - can only add to the reputation of a worthy patron.
I know a little about a great many things: I dabble, sir, I dabble, but I do so 'con brio'!
Rub on the tincture, and all will be well. But, pray you: never drink it.
A rousing tattoo can raise the spirits, stiffen the resolve, and signal an order.
An expert with the blade or pistol is a useful man to consult when honour is impugned.
I will make sure the voter is properly compensated for his ringing endorsement, sir.
Smugglers are a curse upon the good order of any nation, and must be hunted with vigour!
Trade, sir, trade! What else is there for a man of parts? It is the lifeblood of a nation!
Couscous? Imshi!
How?
He is a fool, but he is my fool, sir, and he will have preferment over more able men if I so decide!
He may have a face like a Barbary ape's privities, but he is family and owns an able mind!
For some men being loyal and true is as natural as breathing.
I have no idea what my wife saw in the boy when she arranged matters, other than his enormous inheritance, of course.
A good horse is worth its weight in gold when the lead starts to fly.
A man must have music and gaiety, even as he slaughters his enemies!
Money and the creative uses of it are an Art without, as yet, a Muse.
Without food, water, boots, clothes, guns, powder and a thousand other necessaries, an army marches nowhere.
OGUPI VSMTRS FYJOD UPIST RSVAR BRTPA FDYOV LSMFF RDRTB RSQTO XRPTN OHVIF FARDY PQUPI STRMP YHRYY OMHRO YJRTY JPIHJ DYPQM PYGTP ZZRDY PQ
Honest merchants need have nothing to fear!
An exotic bloom, in no other ruler's possession naturally, must have tender care.
The righteous ruler can expect the full support of the Orthodox Church.
A lubricious and vigorous account of a duchess and her unseemly behaviour, illustrated copiously and with lecherous detail, can do much to inflame or to distract.
No, sir, they will pay. And you will see the money in the public coffers by and by.
No matter how reasonable the tax, sir, even good men will work ceaselessly to avoid all payment!
A man who will see a thief hanged, and not profit by its lack, is dangerous and worth keeping to hand.
Trade is war, sir! It is war fought out with cruelty and no quarter. Your battle, sir, is a pale reflection of a trader's work!
Free trade, sir! Pah! I paid good money not to hear talk of 'free' anything!
There is always a taste for the exotic and Oriental to be satisfied.
There are many companies worth investment, but only my stock offers a guaranteed 10,000 per centum return!
Children are not always a requirement for enjoying the services of a strict governess.
Seen one bloody ruin, seen them all, old thing. Is there any more port?
Men, sir, respond well to the voice of command, even as it orders them to their deaths.
A good piece, whether for fowling or bringing down a man, requires craftsmanship.
A lie has power; the truth, clearly written, has more.
I owe him my life. That is not a debt to be lightly paid.
A fierce man, from a bleak land of fierce men, can be useful in a tight corner.
"I apologise for calling your wife a bloated warthog and bid you good day!"
A talented young man, but desperately in want of an adequate fortune.
Measuring God's Creation is a matter of precision and good instrumentation, not guesswork!
The search for truth requires an inquiring mind, and a steady hand if one is not to be killed.
There are many paths to wisdom, but only one destination worthy of the faithful.
Watching the heavens and thereby keeping the calendar correct are tasks for a faithful man.
Learning comes in many forms, some older than the words of the Prophet (peace be upon him).
It was the will of Allah, the Merciful.
Piracy? No! I do but fish for the enemies of Allah, according to His mercy and their wealth.
All men must follow the course that God has ordained for them.
The enemies of God are right to fear such a man, guided by righteous anger.
The wise ruler knows when to provide someone else for the people to hate.
Man's justice can be nothing but flawed when Allah, the Merciful, is ignored.
There is no higher law than the will of Allah, the Merciful. Remember that, and the rest follows as night does day.
The laws of Islam are firm and fair, but the truth of a matter may be harder to find in a man's words.
God willing, the cure will take effect soon.
Piety is a sharp sword in the armoury of the faithful.
In the name of Allah, the Merciful, the Compassionate, hear the words…
A man who protects the faith and the faithful is truly the Sword of the Righteous in the Hand of God!
Learning is surely the gift of Allah, the Compassionate.
There are many ways to Allah, the Merciful, and a wise man considers them all.
Only a few men can truly teach the way of the Sufi.
I have not turned my back on Allah, only on those so-called servants of God who played me false!
Truth cannot be silenced forever, even if the presses are smashed!
The lower orders, sir, are born in guilt. They require nothing but detection and punishment.
Guilt, sir, or innocence! All other considerations, from your father's title to size of your damned purse, are as nothing to me.
Law and order require enforcement, sometimes seemingly cruel enforcement, for the common good of all.
Woof?
Law, sir, is what separates us from savages of wilder climes. It is the highest calling of a gentleman.
I think, sir, that the law exists for gentlemen, and not for the scum of the streets.
My coat, sir, may not be of the latest cut, but you will find my arguments as cutting as any tailor's shears.
A gentleman should always be judged by the state of his linen.
The gift of the Moon People, nourished by their pale illumination, is not lightly cast aside.
Aye, 'appen we can make yon contraption in quantity.
A broadside, well delivered, is a powerful counter-argument to any whippersnapper demanding that the colours be struck.
Keeping the works on course demands a strong hand, a clerk's eye for detail, and an admiral's authority.
I say, the little buggers have a scent! View halloo!
The man who knows horseflesh can name his own price.
Being able to bridge a river, build a road, or create a fortress are skills much admired by wise generals.
A man may become expert in military matters without troubling to attend a battle.
For every man in an army, there is at least a dozen pieces of paperwork!
Pillow talk need not always be of love. Sometimes careers can be made or broken by a word.
To bed a woman is a pleasure; to bed one famed for her skills adds a certain something.
A woman's tongue, even as it pleases, can do immeasurable damage with a word in the wrong place.
He is a great comfort and constant, inseparable companion, you know.
A general must have some comfort, from time to time.
Oooh, sir, are you going to take your boots off this time?
She's my niece if I say she's my bloody niece! Now, sir, look to your own domestic arrangements!
What say we slice an oik or two, do for a whore or three and then - a bottle?
There are baubles aplenty in the world, but this stone shines above them all.
My girls are all initiates at the Temple of Venus, sir, and most willing to please a gentleman of quality!
Reason and Science will mark the coming Age. The time of superstition is done.
The wind may blow as it will, but it is paper that moves ships.
The ship is wanting in every aspect. It is a bucket, pretending to be a ship. I would sooner set sail in a stockpot.
A man who can find his way across the trackless seas is valuable indeed.
Aye, aye, sir!
This man's appetite for wine, women and song know few bounds, and he does not care much for singing.
Having a price on one's head is flattering, certainly, but a trifle wearing when so many are trying to collect it.
"...and then the bloody chambermaid had a screaming fit, simply because I removed her..."
The Austrian state has seen fit to honour this man for his long service.
The Danish state has seen fit to honour this man for his services.
The British monarch has seen fit to honour this man for his meritorious conduct.
The Crown has honoured this man for his service to France.
France has seen fit to publicly honour this man for his long service.
The Dutch state is pleased to honour the services of this worthy gentleman.
The Porte is pleased to recognise this man's services to the Ottoman state.
This man's long and worthy services to the Polish state has been rewarded with this honour.
Prussia is justifiably proud in honouring one of its sons with this noble Order.

ancillaries.onscreen_name: Grand Cross of the Iron Cross
ancillaries.colour_text: This Prussian has been honoured for his outstanding military service.

ancillaries.onscreen_name: Order of Saint Andrew the First-Called
ancillaries.colour_text: The Tsar's Court is pleased to honour this man for his most excellent service to the Motherland.
This North British gentleman has been honoured for his worthy service.
The Spanish Court is pleased to honour this man for his long and noble service.
The Swedish state is proud that such a military man can be recognised for his services.
The Swedish state is honoured to present this gentleman with such a prestigious Order.
The Swedish state is proud that such a learned man can be recognised for his services.
The services of this worthy American are rightly commemorated by this handsome award.
Harken to my voice! My master is far too important to speak your ridiculous gabble!
Every building requires a man to keep the labourers at honest toil, and the tradesmen satisfied.
Woof!
My advice is direct, sir: settle your account! Your health depends on it. Good day.
Long years afloat give a man an eye for the sea and its moods.
The skirl of the pipes puts iron in a man's stride, and a powerful fear in enemy bowels.
A hot press can produce a surprising quantity of seamen.
Feck! Celibacy! Arse! Bloody nuns!
My faith is still strong, although my breeches sometimes weaken!
There is drinking. And there is whoring, drinking, gambling, and cruel, vicious pleasure in the utter ruination of others for idle sport.
This collection of quirks natural and unnatural, curios, relics and oddities does much to shed light on the wonders of God's Creation.
A mind benefits from the illumination afforded by other thinkers.
He has the benefit of my confidences, sir, because he is my only true friend at court!
Dress him how you will, a silk stocking full of shit is never going to pass for a gentleman.
A nimble lad, and a cool head on young shoulders.
This man is uninfected by any tinge of mercy towards his fellow men.
One shot, one kill.
A good ship needs a master's hand to give life to the wood.
The business of reducing a fortress is a matter of time, guns, and mathematics.
Even the finest admiral in the world needs to have his orders seen and obeyed.
A coat cut in the latest style says much about a man's self respect.
An able governor can often apply his skills to many problems of state.
The defenders of the Porte are the best men to honour the time-hallowed customs of ruling the Empire.
The janissaries have defended the Empire for centuries, and remain its surest shield.
Loyalty in a secretary is important.
One man's luxury is another man's necessity.
There are many uses for a truly able man, one who can cut through the tangle of government as with a sword.
Truly, the height of ambition is to possess your own turnip.
My people understand loyalty, and a whip in their master's hand.
I do not drink...wine.
Sir, my vote was not bought for a pittance! I expected and received proper recompense!
This lady's virtue shines with a noble light, and so illuminates her husband's career.
A woman's quick wits can do much to advance a husband's career.
After a battle my husband is always prostate with grief, you know.
Happiness? What has that to do with marriage when there are prospects to consider?
Being cuckolded may be worthwhile, if it fathers preferment.
A manservant from the Dark Continent is a most fashionable addition to a household of quality.
The power to cloud minds and so control men through the science of fluid magnetism should never be underestimated!
ancillaries.explanation_text: This man can help spies and other nefarious men achieve their vile ends.

ancillaries.colour_text: There's more to wine than finding the next bucket of claret.
Cruelty can wear a winning smile, even as it drinks and whores and gambles its way through another man's fortune.
A clever general surrounds himself with young men of talent.
"Sadly, his mother - while big with the boy - was frightened by a particularly ignorant horse."
A prayer is as good as a sabre, when the day is in doubt.
"An army, Sir, is only of any damned use when it has marched to the right place and can give battle!"
This man has changed his allegiance; his savagery towards his own kind quells any doubts as to his loyalties.
A good horse, and enough guts for a regiment of dragoons, have taken this man far across enemy territory.
A timely message can avert many a crisis in battle.
A flattering account of one's life is, well, flattering, but should never be believed.
Denied promotion at home, this man has offered his skills to the highest bidder.
An interest in horseflesh has taken this man far from home, and into foreign service.
A life spent watching officers ruin battles has brought this man to some strange new masters.
The man who can map the significant military features of a landscape can show the path to victory.
The ability to understand the landscape can show the path of least resistance.
Captured in battle, this man has proven to be surprisingly loyal to those who spared his life.
"Your tackle may be aflame, sir, but unless you apply the ointment as I have instructed your breeches will continue to smoulder!"
"Supplies - good boots, say - keep a soldier happy and healthy just as well as not getting shot!"
Speed and dexterity with the knife, saw and needle are the basic accomplishments of any good surgeon.
When an army marches, it must carry all its necessaries with it.
Well-placed artillery can settle many an argument.
ancillaries.explanation_text: This officer can help with the use and management of artillery units.

ancillaries.colour_text: "Pies are my second passion, Sir, after a well-presented and properly bled client..."
Scholars - medical or not - should never be hampered by the vagaries of law or petty morality. They need flesh!
A man who can stand 167 rounds of bareknuckle boxing can be useful in a tight spot.
"It will be my pleasure, Signor, to see my principal's name carved into your heart!"
If a man won't duel over honour, perhaps he should be provided with another excuse?
"BANG!"
The perfect weapon for a man with a killer's eye.
"These new almonds are a little on the bitter side."
"It don't suit everyone. The hours are long, you have to like your own company, and the cave's bloody drafty. Still - better than starving, eh?"
"No structure, placed harmoniously within a landscape, is entirely wasted, Sir!"
Accurate accounting is a boon to good government - and to personal wealth, if a man's mind runs that way.
Building is far more than making sure the bricks are laid properly.
If a man wakes up with a hangover and the memory of a warm woman, it may ease the shock of joining the army.
There is nothing wrong with reading another man's letters, especially when there are messages hidden within.
A man who can kill in so many inventive ways should be allowed to practice his skills.
"Yes, his tongue was cut out, but he will throw himself on an assassin's blade to save me!"
The best place to look for treachery is in the shadows.
The business of managing an empire necessitates lengthy correspondence, copious minutes, voluminous regulation, and a big bottle of ink.
"I move in very exalted circles, you know! Oh, the things I could tell you, if I only had the time..."
A man who can weave plots, schemes, counterplots, and counter-counterplots into a web of deceit is valuable.
"The rich have what is worth stealing. The poor steal. These are immutable rules of nature."
The cross, the hawthorn stake, the sharp blade and garlic: virtuous tools in the hands of the righteous.
"If you do not tell the truth, I promise my servant will show you the meaning of agony."
The great occasions of state demand music - new music, original music - to dazzle and amaze the listening crowd.
A man who knows the backwoods and hidden trails will always find a way to flank an enemy.
History judges all men, but if the evidence is carefully marshalled the verdict may be kind.
"The finding of new oceans, seas and lakes upon the Moon most assuredly gives the discoverer the right to name them as he and his patron desire!"
"My main study is a matter vital - vital - to our prosperity, Sir. I speak of nothing less than the safe enlargement of trouser mice!"
ancillaries.explanation_text: This man's work may not be as useful in all fields of endeavour as he maintains.

ancillaries.colour_text: "The world will beat a path to your door, Sir. Invest but a small sum in the 'Jiggling Elizabeth', and everyone will thank you!"
A man who can be utterly damning from the witness box is useful, even when he doesn't know the accused.
"The village - and the tenants - must be removed, otherwise the proposed lake will be in want of an harmonious aspect."
Studying the broken mind can lead to fruitful insights into the soul.
"I, Sir, not fashion or whimsy or the opinions of the great and good, decide what constitutes sanity at this juncture!"
"Profit, sir, keeps a roof over the heads of honest landowners! If the whining poor choose not to pay the market price, so be it!"
"A good horseman sits well, Sir. Dash and fire come later, to those unlucky enough not to be Hungarian!"
"Please, my love: no more bishop jokes this evening..."
Gorgeous, headstrong and loyal to her master, even to the point of death.
Cheap entertainment keeps one in touch with common folk.
Not every lady is ladylike, which is why this lady has an extremely comfortable life.
Not every lady is as ladylike as he (ahem!) would have everyone believe.
Knowing the right people to bribe or blackmail can do wonders for a man's career.
A woman with the right connections may see things that others do not.
This woman is a spider: merciless, hypnotic, seductive and, to her enemies, deadly.
A terribly wise fellow. Close-mouthed, of course, but shockingly wise.
The wise see what the foolish do not. Sometimes they tell the foolish about their visions.
Solace can be found in more than a jug of grog.
A wise admiral makes use of an extra pair of young eyes.
A life of adventure on the high seas has brought this man far from his Hollander roots.
Guns, sails, hull, crew: all must be in harmonious proportion.
Inspection by an unsympathetic eye may make a captain look like a fool, but can save his ship.
The man who gets the best price for a ship and its cargo is a useful - and popular - fellow.
"What others term short rations, I call prudence!"
"I'll wager, Sir, that you've never seen tunny leaping out of the sea at midnight..."
A man who can keep his head when the decks are awash with blood is worth his weight in cannon balls.
The work of master craftsmen, this precision timepiece is a priceless aid to navigators.
Debasing coinage is a serious offence - unless the government are the people doing it.
Music is one of the civilized accomplishments of any age.
Mostly truthful reporting of government business is a powerful tool for a minister.
The right kind of truth in reporting of government business is helpful to an agent provocateur.
A gentleman of quality should always take care of himself, avoid exertion, and sit down to six or seven good meals a day.
Sometimes even a monkey has secrets.
"I am in want of a rhyme: 'While his enemies are like hens clucking, he busies himself with much...' but I am stumped!"
"Sitting uncomfortably? Good - then we'll begin. Now, deep breaths between screams..."
The gift of a grateful nation for defeats inflicted on treacherous foreigners.
A mark of favour for a naval career of much distinction.
A wise bawd knows her customer's preferences, and far too many of their secrets.
"My principal wishes to know if you will give him an apology - or should I arrange for an undertaker to call?"
"Sir, like many educated men of the cloth, I find the actress joke 'ad infinitum' rapidly becomes 'ad nauseam!'"
Knowledge of the Prophet, peace be upon him, can only help a man lead his people.
The wise man remembers that there is a dividing line between righteous anger and personal ambition.
"We must build the new Jerusalem, in this blessed land, and deliver all our people from the temptations of the flesh."
"Books, Sir, are the repository of wisdom."
"Poor Jack's mad! Mad, he is. But when the moon is new: why, good sir, then Jack knows the darkest secrets!"
"It's my experience, Sir, that there's many a gentleman who would benefit from a good stuffing."
Collecting taxes is an unpopular business, but huge profits usually soothe the pain of being loathed.
A good woman, with a sharp tongue, can do much to advance a gentleman's prospects - and damage those of rivals.
"Call yourself a husband? Why didn't I listen to Mother? She said you would amount to nothing! What good are you? Bah!"
"He's resting"
"Fart-breath Dutch sausage hounds! Spanish pox-monkeys! English mollies! Bloody Frenchmen!! SQUAWK!"
"Who's a pretty boy, then? Squawk!"
Locks guard secrets, and in a world of secrets the man who can open locks is a valuable asset.
"Haha! Ole ole!!!"

ancillaries.onscreen_name: Son of a Shameless Guitar Plucker
ancillaries.colour_text: "I’m not the shameless plucker, I’m the shameless plucker’s son…"
"Que? I’m sorry...he’s from Barcelona"
